Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Alaska Native Leaders Knowledge: Impact on Policy Implementation and Resource Management
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the dissertation research of an Alaska Native PhD student. Using anthropological methods of ethnographic interviews, open-ended surveys, and archival research, the project will examine the intersection between the formal legal definitions of hunting and fishing rights among the Aleuts of Alaska and local traditional knowledge of these rights. This research will contribute to a discussion of the relationship between knowledge and power in the context of resource management and control in Alaska.

The broader impacts of this research are its contributions to the training of the CoPI, a Phd Candidate and an Alaska Native woman, thus increasing the representation of this highly underrepresented group in the social sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this award included the education of a female Indigenous scholar, and opportunities for sharing at findings the community, regional, national and international meeting levels. This dissertation contributed to the discourse about Indigenous knowledge in policy and natural resource management. It also discussed the dynamics and the workload associated with serving on boards in small Alaskan communities. 

The central question of this dissertation was, “What do Aleut people know about the laws that directly affect their access to local resources?” The complex details of hunting and fishing regulations coupled with legislation that dictates access to natural resources played a key role in Aleut leaders’ ability to understand, disseminate, and protect these rights. Such policies include clauses that regulate who can and cannot participate based on blood quantum, which can be problematic for future generations of Aleut people as they marry and have children with people from outside the region. Further, with the abolishment of aboriginal title to lands and hunting and fishing rights in Alaska, understanding who owns the land and resources and how they are governed is imperative to Aleut people. This dissertation used participant observation, critical case studies, key informant interviews, and a survey of Aleut leaders in the Eastern Aleutians to illustrate the ways in which Aleut people know and understand their environment and the ways they address natural resource management issues. It further demonstrated the way these issues are being addressed and learned about in two Eastern Aleutian communities. It also highlighted the dynamic leadership of Aleut community members in the Eastern Aleutians. Some of the major findings include no reported change in subsistence use for respondents under the age of 50, a decline in the amount of subsistence used by older respondents, Aleut leaders spend years serving their communities in multiple capacities; and generally speaking, younger generations of public servants tend to become involved in community service as well.

The research led the scholar to a full-time position and also allowed her to collaborate and expand on the knowledge that she gained through this research experience. It provided a unique emic perspective about Indigenous knowledge about legislation in rural Alaska and provided a better understanding of how relationships between people and the policies that affect them translates forward. This research contributed to Indigenous ethnography by adding a dialogue from the emic perspective and formulates a better understanding of what Aleuts in the Eastern Aleutians know about land claims, fishing rights and local access to resources. This study provided a timely and much needed discourse about the changes that are being felt within the Native communities throughout Alaska. This research has valuable contributions to anthropology, political ecology, globalization and Indigenous Studies.
